thread.title: Humans Aren’t The Only Creatures to Make Nostalgic Returns Home | Kenneth P. Dietrich School of Arts & Sciences | University of Pittsburgh
thread.title_full: Humans Aren’t The Only Creatures to Make Nostalgic Returns Home | Kenneth P. Dietrich School of Arts & Sciences | University of Pittsburgh

title: Humans Aren’t The Only Creatures to Make Nostalgic Returns Home | Kenneth P. Dietrich School of Arts & Sciences | University of Pittsburgh
text: Each fall, universities and schools across the U.S. celebrate homecoming, welcoming alums back to campus to reconnect with old friends and places held dear. But humans aren’t the only ones with a propensity to return to familiar places. [Corinne Richards-Zawacki](https://www.biology.pitt.edu/person/zawacki), professor of biology in the Kenneth P. Dietrich School of Arts and Sciences and director of the [Pymatuning Laboratory of Ecology](https://www.ple.pitt.edu/), studies natal philopatric amphibians, that is, amphibians that habitually return to the place where they were born to reproduce. You can read the full story in [PittWire](https://www.pitt.edu/pittwire/features-articles/2024/09/18/homecoming-philopatric-amphibians-richards-zawacki?utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=0919%20Bethel%20biobank%20Spanish-speaking%20lab%20homecoming%20migration%20overton&utm_content=0919%20Bethel%20biobank%20Spanish-speaking%20lab%20homecoming%20migration%20overton+CID_0b0064a51832f738dfbaaed237f3f478&utm_source=CM%20Pittwire&utm_term=explains%20the%20instinct%20in%20animals).
